speaker: SPEAKER_02

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so the paradigm has to do with something like collective problem solving, where you have agents and networks, they're collectively solving a problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The problem is based in what's called an NK landscape.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And it's basically just
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: basically agents seek to find the best solution to an abstract or hypothetical problem.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You have a whole ranking system where there are a series of potential solutions represented in some number of bits or digits.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then there's some degree, some kind of complexity parameter that you can use such that whenever you increase it, it's as if,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: changing your problem a little bit can dramatically change how good it is.

text: One quick way of saying it is like, well,
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If you want to design a car, if you remove the wheels, it's going to be a terrible car.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: You just changed one piece of it, and yet the entire solution, the entire schematic that you've built for your car is junk now.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So that's the idea.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: There are these solutions agents are trying to solve that have a lot of interdependencies between the different parts of the solution.

text: So let's see.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so usually the agents are not really integrated.

text: They're not agents in any way that we've learned about agents in active inference.

text: It represents that.

text: Again, I wrote this for an audience who might not have any awareness of what active inference is, but it's still a computational social science audience, and so they will be presumably familiar with agent-based modeling.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I include some guidelines on just modeling really anything agent-based modeling, but otherwise four common principles.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: The first one, verisimilitude, which is basically just to say, are we making realistic assumptions?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Whenever we set up a model, an agent, and we have to make a series of assumptions.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And so do we...
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Does the audience, do the readers, do they agree with those assumptions?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Are they reasonable to make?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Is there any kind of empirical support for the assumptions you're making?
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: If not, then suddenly we have some very faulty scaffolding for the entire simulation that's to come.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: That said, we also need robustness.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Tiny changes to the model presumably should not lead to dramatic changes in the final outcome.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Otherwise, what you've done is that you've created a simulation or a model that's a little overfit that really works well for a particular circumstance, but not so much for
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: just about anything else you'd wanna use it for.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Reproducibility is really important.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I wanted to be very transparent in making this tutorial.

text: I made all the slides available.

text: All the code is available.

speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: I can share that again with you all.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And then finally, number four, non-triviality, which would just be ideally we would actually extract insights from doing agent-based modeling or in our case, active inference.

speaker: SPEAKER_02
